Join us for this special event to network, learn and celebrate excellence.

St. Jude Children's Research Hospital

The Hub Intranet Redesign

St. Jude’s revamped intranet helps frontline heroes find the info they need faster

St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital’s mission is to cure childhood cancer, and achieving that goal requires a workforce equipped with the tools, resources, information and community to keep them thriving and saving lives. For its ambitious intranet overhaul, St. Jude has earned the Grand Prize for Best Overall Intranet in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards.

Facing a cluttered intranet with over 6,800 pages and frustrated employees, St. Jude’s communications team embarked on an eight-month overhaul project shaped by user needs and employee feedback.

Their goals were to create “a digital workplace that is user-friendly, with features that enhance productivity, encourage collaboration, patient care, basic science laboratory research and administrative services.”

The result was the St. Jude Hub. The changes included:

Reducing page count by 82%, meaning employees spent less time sifting through outdated content and more time focusing on their critical roles in fighting childhood cancer.

An improved search function with intuitive filters, allowing employees to quickly find the information they need. As a result, employees spend an average of 41 seconds less browsing search result pages than they did before the change.

A customizable experience that allows employees to mark favorite pages and save important documents, forms and links for quick access.

A responsive mobile experience that is available as a native Microsoft Teams application, which helps frontline workers access the Hub on the go.

The “St. Jude Today” daily digest, which keeps employees informed about upcoming events, campus news and employee achievements.

An internal “phonebook,” which allows for easy colleague and department searches. It has seen significant usage since its launch.

Since launch, the hub has seen a user adoption rate of 99.5%, with more than 40,000 daily page views.

The hub is not just a repository of information, though – it’s a powerful tool that empowers employees, fosters collaboration and strengthens the fight against childhood cancer. Congratulations to the team for developing this award-winning experience.

T-Mobile

Magenta Giving 2023

T-Mobile unites employees and makes a splash with ‘Magenta Giving’ campaign

T-Mobile’s “Magenta Giving” campaign aimed to foster a sense of pride and connection among T-Mobile employees while aiding communities across the U.S. This communications initiative has earned the Grand Prize for Employee Communication Campaign of the Year in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards.

Three years after a major merger and following the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic, the communications team at T-Mobile needed to create a sense of unity among its employees. Launched in April 2023, “Magenta Giving” reinforced T-Mobile’s culture and provided a platform for employees to connect with their passions and communities.

For employees in main offices, in-person volunteers were encouraged to join events aimed at addressing hunger, educational equity and the environment. Participants packed meals for Harvesters, an organization that seeks to improve access to nutritious food; planted trees at Farmer Frog, which cultivates community gardens in underserved neighborhoods; and assembled kits for students at City Year, which prepares students in underserved schools for graduation, college and their careers. Leaders in T-Mobile’s different locations connected with similar local activities such as donation drives and volunteer events.

To encourage participation, the communications team developed regular emails with video messages from leadership, informative intranet content, a dedicated “Magenta Giving” landing page, social media updates on Slack and digital signage placed across the country.

Additional facets of the campaign included:

Giving accounts and matching: T-Mobile Foundation seeded employee giving accounts with $23 each and doubled volunteered hours with a $20 per hour match.

Educational webcasts: Sessions about T-Mobile’s philanthropic partners, such as Project 10Million and Welcome.US, educated employees about making a difference.

“Magenta Giving” champions: These designated employees within each team promoted ways to give, generated excitement and encouraged participation.

As a result, T-Mobile employees and the organization’s matching donated over $1.9 million to 7,041 nonprofits, surpassing the campaign’s goals. Employees spent more than 16,000 hours volunteering and serving their local communities. The campaign was met with overwhelmingly positive feedback, with 95% of employees surveyed wanting to participate again next year.

And it isn’t over: After a successful inaugural year, “Magenta Giving” is shaping up to become a tradition at T-Mobile.

Congratulations to T-Mobile’s communications team for leading this initiative.

Genesys

Comms Driving Company Strategy

Genesys’ workforce ‘flies in formation’ around the world

Genesys’ dedicated employee communications team has been recognized with the Grand Prize for Employee Communications Team of the Year in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards due to its creative approach in aligning a globally dispersed workforce with the company’s vision.

In this post-pandemic world, 95% of Genesys’ 6,500 employees continue to work remotely across over 50 countries, making a sense of community and a universal understanding of the company’s strategy, purpose and values critical for success. Genesys’ seven-person communications team, with three internal communications specialists and four executive leads, stepped up to connect this dispersed employee population.

They drew upon Genesys’ core value concept — “Fly in formation” — to develop an education campaign, events, a content plan and an engagement strategy.

In January, they launched an all-employee education campaign, ensuring everyone understood the upcoming fiscal year’s strategy. This included distributing the CEO’s vision statement and a one-page plan outline, followed by a comprehension test and contests to incentivize listening and understanding.

A kickoff event included keynotes from the CEO, who shared the vision; the chief product officer, who showcased technology leadership; and the chief customer officer, who highlighted customer wins.

The team deployed messaging to support the mission across its intranet, called One Genesys, in addition to a weekly newsletter, quarterly company all-hands meetings and executive communications that emphasized driving growth, customer success, technology innovation, sustainability and key performance metrics.

Meanwhile, to unify leaders and provide them with clarity on the company’s direction, the communications team provided a private communication platform and coordinated regular meetings with the CEO for people of VP titles and higher. They tapped these leaders for employee spotlights to build appreciation and a sense of human connection.

Employee engagement initiatives included an April Fool’s Day email prank from the chief product officer, a virtual party celebrating the One Genesys Portal’s second birthday with surprise appearances by social media stars, a “Genesys Got Talent” competition and employee photo albums capturing company events.

As a result of their efforts, surveys show 92% of employees understand the company’s future plans, and 90% feel informed about goals and priorities. Quarterly all-hands meetings achieve an average of 4,000 attendees and a high satisfaction score, the One Genesys portal has an 80% monthly readership, and the weekly newsletter has a 69% open rate.

Congratulations to the Genesys communications team for their efforts in helping the workforce feel informed, connected and empowered to contribute to the company’s success.

The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society

Communications

How the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society ushered in a new era

When president and CEO Louis J. DeGennaro retired after 18 years at the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS), the organization needed to build trust in its new CEO, E. Anders Kolb, board of directors, and executive and leadership teams. Its ability to reassure and establish a rapport among employees, patients and their families, volunteers, donors, partners and more is the reason it’s being recognized in the Alignment with External Communications category in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards.

A mixternal communications plan began in early 2023, as LLS shared the name of its new president and CEO with employees, patients, volunteers, supports and external constituents on March 8, a few months before his May 1 start date. Part of that included showing how DeGennaro would stay on in an advisory role for two months until his retirement on June 30.

This initial phase ensured that employees and constituents understood the selection process for identifying the new CEO and his new vision.

In announcing Kolb internally, LLS created a post on its intranet and a teaser email that gave staff a heads-up before a live webinar. Their first time “meeting” him was through a showing of an Oprah-style fireside chat with a board of directors member in the webinar, which Kolb and DeGennaro both joined to show a united front.

Externally, constituents were notified with targeted emails or phone calls directly, plus the announcement was shared as a news release and across social channels. An edited-down version of the fireside chat video was also shared.

After Kolb completed his first 100 days, the team followed up with his achievements and opportunities to elevate him through interviews.

The response, both internally and externally, exceeded expectations for the LLS team, including:

The internal “Meet Our New President and CEO” email received 800 opens. The LLS has around 1,000 employees.

A news release blog post on the site saw around 5,000 pageviews.

A “My First 100 Days” post had 964% more viewership than other blog posts.

Kolb’s LinkedIn went from 16 to 594 followers in two months.

Earned media surrounding the change received over 76 million impressions.

Congratulations to the team for the way it handled the transition.

Providence

Providence Annual Report to Our Communities

Providence’s annual report spotlights its highs in detail

The Providence Annual Report to Our Communities highlighted its record-breaking $2.1 billion investment in community benefit, showing how it’s strengthening the communities it serves. This effort has earned it recognition in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards in the Annual Reports category.

The annual report tells community impact stories about the caregivers and partners who brought hope to those in need, upholding Providence’s charitable mission. It focuses on four areas of how the organization is creating healthier communities: foundations of health, removing barriers to care, promoting community resilience and innovating for the future.

Touched by many departments and teams across the organization, they collaborated to plan the launch, socialization and promotion of the annual report, ultimately driving traffic back to its website. Through a unified narrative on the community benefit programs, investments and initiatives around meeting the diverse needs of those it serves, the content is targeted based on audience and location.

The campaign included 31 written stories that showed the impact of investments on its communities, three long-form videos, 10 short-form videos for social media distribution, 14 internal newsletters and inclusion in patient newsletters, a social media campaign for sharing all the assets, infographics and more.

These efforts yielded successful results, such as:

The annual report site received over 1,700 caregiver visits between June 2023 and August 2023, with an additional over 12,700 public visits.

Articles reached more than 59,000 caregivers, with almost 5,000 engaging further.

Earned media reached more than 10 million readers.

Photos and video assets on social media drove more than 2 million impressions, almost 450,000 video views and nearly 5,000 engagements.

This was the first time the Providence communications team came together to design the annual report on this scale. Still, the results established a level of success for the team to aspire toward in future efforts.

Congratulations to the Providence team on this top-notch report.

Discover Financial Services

Inclusions Matters

Discover’s commitment to DE&I is setting an industry standard

By sharing stories of diversity, equity and inclusion (DE&I), Discover Financial Services commits to what it sees as its responsibility to create a culture where differences are valued and respected, which is why it’s being recognized as part of Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards in the Article Series category.

Discover shared honest, vulnerable personal stories of individuals across the company in a monthly message series, emphasizing its belief that people should feel valued, like they belong, and free to be themselves. According to its nomination form, the company hoped to expand and influence an understanding of why DE&I is so important to our culture.

The name Discover chose to represent this series was Inclusion Matters.

To start, Discover worked closely with DE&I partners and employee resource group (ERG) leaders to identify employees whose stories to tell. From there, it wanted to handle telling the stories in a unique way, going beyond an interview that may obscure the authenticity and voice of the storyteller. By sharing nine questions with each person, they got guidelines to follow but could still tell their own stories in their own way without it coming across as an interpretation of their tale.

Since the company wanted to turn this into a series, it determined that a steady cadence of employee stories was the best approach. A story appeared on its intranet on the third Wednesday of every month and was amplified through internal emails, ERG pages, companywide announcements and digital monitors in its various locations.

The impact of these DE&I-focused stories was further driven home by ensuring an understanding of signature months and celebrating stories that aligned with those themes, such as sharing a story of an employee who was the child of a transgender woman during Pride Month.

So far, the series has been the most popular messages delivered internally, with the nine messages shared through September 2023 having been viewed more than 141,000 times. Through its Viva Engage platform or intranet, these stories have an average of over 6,200 views and have received almost 3,000 likes and 645 comments of encouragement. Through August 2023, an engagement index of 60.04 was seen.

These stories have resonated with the Discover team on a deep level, showing the success of this initiative and providing a sense of value and freedom to be themselves for employees.

Congratulations to the Discover communications team for this powerful initiative.

Sonic Automotive, Inc.

Internal Communications for the Launch of Gympass, an Employee Well-being Application

How Sonic Automotive supported employee wellbeing

Following the COVID-19 pandemic, local dealership leaders and human resources partners gave feedback about an increased desire to prioritize employee wellbeing at Sonic Automotive, Inc. By shining a spotlight on its Be Healthy principle in such a way. It is being honored for its efforts in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards in the Benefits Communication category.

To bring this plan to fruition, Sonic Automotive created a platform through Gympass, tasking the communications team with becoming experts on the platform so they could relay it to the company’s more than 10,000 employees and encourage them to engage with it. The company had a goal of getting 3-5% of activations (300-500 employee accounts) within the first six months. The plan was to launch Gympass on April 10.

Once it was decided to use Gympass to achieve the goals of its Be Healthy campaign, the team had two months to formulate a communications plan. This began with utilizing any and every communications channel available to inform employees about the platform, including email, an internal application called Workplace by Meta, physical materials and digital outreach. Internal culture committee ambassadors called the Connections Team, also disseminated information. For instance, posters were sent to each location with information about the platform and a QR code, and digital screensavers were deployed to all company devices on April 1.

Once it went live, an email and Workplace post was sent to all employees in addition to communications directly from Gympass. On April 13, employees were reminded of the platform through a town hall hosted on Workplace, with subsequent posts shared in the first month. After about a month, a live Q&A was held in Workplace with Gympass’ customer support team to answer employee questions.

Along with the platform, Sonic Automotive also created its first-ever employee resource group, Well @ Work, to help support employees’ physical, mental and financial wellbeing.

During the two-month period of promoting Gympass, the 15 Workplace posts saw over 3,300 total views and 974 unique views, which ended up being about 18% of the total Workplace user base and 64% of monthly active users. Additionally, the company received positive testimonials from employees.

As of June, there had been 3,430 member downloads of the application, approximately 31% of invited users. They also saw 2,849 gym check-ins across 159 gyms and 113 cities, far surpassing its initial 300-500 enrolled user goal.

Congratulations to Sonic Automotive for accelerating its commitment to wellbeing.

Businessolver

Workspace Anywhere

Businnessolver found a lasting solution during an unprecedented time

When the COVID-19 pandemic first began in 2020, Businessolver confronted challenges that most businesses faced: maintaining a productive — and healthy — workplace for employees. That’s why the company shifted to a fully remote model through its Workspace Anywhere policy, which has landed it a win in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards in the Best Remote Work Experience/Culture category.

In the three years since it first implemented the policy, it has expanded its talent outreach to all 50 states rather than only being confined to the metropolitan areas near its offices. It now has more than 1,500 full-time employees based in 42 states.

In implementing its remote-only strategies in 2020, the company checked in weekly via virtual employee communications and with Employee Pulse surveys. Pre-pandemic saw 85% of pulses at blue or green (feeling happy and productive in their roles), compared to 90% today.

Another way the organization has helped make the transition seamless for its employees was by getting in on yet another pandemic-era trend: implementing AI to create transcripts of member calls to help its member services team better serve members. Plus, its AI assistant, Sofia, can work directly with members to help them better understand their coverage and the platform. This “Tech with Heart” approach allows the company to ensure clients have a level playing field to access coverage and wellness options.

One of the biggest challenges in transitioning to a fully remote workplace was building a more transparent and communicative environment. This included weekly debriefs through its What’s Goin’ On internal communications and the daily Businessolver Way, team standups and e-learning modules and more individual communications, like one-on-ones with managers.

The business finalized its transition in March 2020 and has seen only positive results since. This includes employee engagement improving by 5% between 2020 and 2021, more than 86% of the team feeling supported by the company and that it promotes wellbeing and over 97% sharing that they feel productive working remotely.

Clearly, the team is aligned with this new business model.

Congratulations to Businessolver for taking RTO to the next level.

Cisco (We Are Cisco)

We Are Cisco Blog

Cisco’s blog is all about building connections

The We Are Cisco blog prioritizes storytelling to connect the world with its employees by crafting personal connections and sharing employee-generated content through a #WeAreCisco social campaign. In doing so, it’s been honored in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards in the Blog category.

Beyond just offering glimpses into life at Cisco, the blog also hosts an annual #LoveWhereYouWork contest where employees post on Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn and the internal Webex Space to share why they love their jobs. Winning submissions are then awarded prizes over the span of weeks.

Since the blog doesn’t focus on any single topic, it highlights a range of Cisco employee experiences: a sense of belonging within its Inclusive Communities, internships, opportunities to give back and career growth.

The team identifies whether a story is a good fit for the blog and then fosters a relationship with that employee so it can be shared with a larger audience. The Cisco team provides guidelines but ensures that the post is written in the employees’ words, works with them on edits and maintains their unique voices.

After a post goes live, the We Are Cisco team will amplify it through social media posts across its social channels and LinkedIn page. A social media ambassador, through Sprinklr, then amplifies their colleagues’ posts to extend the post’s reach.

Between September 2022 and September 2023, the blog published 50 stories that received 115,000 views. The top three posts focused on employee wins: a #LoveWhereYouWork winner, a collaborative piece on why employees love the company and a piece highlighting learnings from a first year at Cisco.

But Cisco doesn’t measure success solely based on numerical metrics. The comments it has received on posts have been supportive, engaging and inspiring, showing the true value of the initiative for the company.

Congratulations to the team at Cisco.

TransUnion, Inc.

TransUnion Internal Communications Team

How TransUnion’s communications team led it through an extensive transition

When TransUnion acquired three companies between December 2021 and April 2022, bringing on about 4,000 new employees, the communications team had to integrate people, processes and systems across three companies. This integration process earned TransUnion a win in the Change Communication category of Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards.

From the first day of these integrations, TransUnion sought to keep employees motivated and engaged to support its 42 different workstreams and unite over 12,000 employees under the “One TransUnion” mindset.

The strategy was based on three pillars: inform and connect employees with accurate information; engage, train and educate employees on the “TransUnion way”; and inspire and demonstrate the employee value proposition.

It focused on:

Retaining talent to keep employees engaged and productive.

Creating a playbook that targeted both integrated and heritage teams at every level.

Integrating the different technology systems so they all fold into the technology infrastructure.

Crafting a strategy that integrated processes across all teams from the newly acquired companies.

Adjusting the “business as usual” communications strategy to reach new employees considering accessibility, relevance, context, purpose and persona.

The team created an employee onboarding campaign that saw more than 80% engagement, aligning and leveling employees across the organization during six months, which required 100% engagement and a 20-month-long campaign with over 15 campaigns and a toolkit of support assets.

For TransUnion, the integrations are performing as expected so far.

Feedback from employees over 100 days has been mostly positive, with more than 80% expressing excitement to see how their organization will fit within the larger company.

The three “Connect” intranet sites created have also received more than 150,000 visits.

The All In onboarding series had a high engagement.

The total 112 “Scoop” newsletters received more than 10,000 page visits.

TransUnion communications plan aligned close to 4,000 employees and contractors and received much positive direct feedback.

Congratulations to the TransUnion team on this successful initiative.

Wray Ward

EmpoWWer Service-Grant Program

Wray Ward is a champion of the Charlotte creative community

Wray Ward builds awareness, drives interest and creates engagement for its clients as well as local nonprofits and community organizations, serving as a voice for these organizations and underserved members of the communities they help. This dedication and support for nonprofits earned the agency a win in the Community Relations category of Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards.

After launching its EmpoWWer service and grant program in 2018, Wray Ward has raised more than $700,000 in donations, which support 15 nonprofits in Charlotte, N.C., where the organization is based. Wray Ward creates marketing communications strategies for these organizations using these funds.

The program is supported by the pillars of creativity, shelter, and advancement to help the nonprofits accomplish their missions, including combating systemic racism and gentrification, supporting local teachers, fostering youth confidence, supporting local artists, providing free housing for patients who need medical care and more.

Each year, Wray Ward selects three or four nonprofits to work closely with, including brand photography, a new logo, a social media campaign or a video series. Employees can volunteer to participate in the EmpoWWer project, and many have continued to participate after the project ended.

For its 2022-2023 participants, Wray Ward worked with:

United Way of Greater Charlotte requested a marketing strategy to increase understanding and support for its mission.

In working with United Way, Wray Ward evolved the brand with new design elements, photography and messaging to go with its new name. The agency also created workplace campaigns and strategies for social, email marketing, public relations and more.

PFLAG Charlotte, which wanted to promote its LGBTQ+ and gender-affirming resources.

Wray Ward created two videos about its workshops, supplied communications and PR tools and crafted a social media plan and rebrand launch event.

Charlotte Art League, which wanted to create awareness around its public gallery and visual arts offerings through a new logo and brand ethos.

The agency refreshed its logo, offered photography guidelines and best practices, and created PR, communications and social media strategies.

The agency’s measure of success is its ability to help these organizations reach their business goals and the positive feedback they receive.

Congratulations to Wray Ward for its commitment to benefiting its community.

JK Design

The Children's Place 2022 Environment, Social & Governance (ESG) Report

How JK Design crafted an ESG report that tells a story worth aspiring to

Sustainable business practices have been an integral part of The Children’s Place development from a brick-and-mortar storefront to becoming the largest children’s specialty apparel retailer. In working with the company, JK Design upheld these values and scored a win in the CSR/ESG Report category of Ragan’s Employee Communications Awards.

The 2022 report outlines the retailer’s ESG strategy, progress and targets while also showing its commitment to sustainability and responsible business practices in a way that is engaging and memorable to employees, investors and candidates.

Working with JK Design, the goal was to tell a cohesive story, making the complex data accessible and clear. After a workflow was established between the two teams, The Children’s Place chose a “whimsical, fingerprint-inspired style rooted in its playful, youthful spirit,” according to the nomination form.

In creating the report, JK Design delivered a compelling package with interactive navigation, simplified content, a visually digestible design with thoughtfully deployed white space, vibrant people and nature-focused photography, infographics and data tools, and testimonials from employees.

To share it with key stakeholders, The Children’s Place executed a communications plan that included:

An ESG webpage on its corporate website where anyone could download the full report, which has been downloaded approximately 1,400 times so far.

A press release, which lives on the NewsPlace section of its site.

An email from the CEO to its 870 employees.

An article in the employee newsletter and intranet site.

Highlights in the Q2 2023 investor relations deck.

Stakeholders have expressed appreciation for its accessible, digestible nature and were impressed by the information found in the report.

Congratulations to JK Design for this well-earned win.

Seattle Children's Hospital

Seattle Children's Email Communications: Evolving Every Day

Seattle Children’s Hospital reaches busy employees efficiently via email

Unsurprisingly, the workforce at Seattle Children’s Hospital is exceedingly busy at any given time of the workday and, therefore, relies on email for company communications to effectively do their jobs. The strategies it deploys in reaching its 14,000-person workforce have earned it an honor in the Email Communication category of Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards.

The organization regularly reevaluates its efforts of communicating with its employees, finding the outlets and channels to reach the right people efficiently. Therefore, messaging is highly targeted and personalized for its audiences. This includes:

InHouse newsletter sent to all members weekly, which saw 700,000 emails sent across 50 campaigns over the last fiscal year.

Provider updates are sent to all MDs, ARNPs, residents, fellows and more weekly.

Leadership Message sent to supervisors and higher weekly.

Central Broadcasting, which are single-topic emails reserved for emergencies.

Further, over the course of a six-week period, Seattle Children’s Hospital saw more than 39,000 sessions, over 279,000 events and a 62.51% engagement rate on its intranet from just one newsletter.

To continue improving upon the process, the hospital worked with an outside vendor to survey employees to understand what was working and what needed improvement. The biggest piece of feedback that came through this effort was that people want more visually appealing messaging, so the team is working to onboard a new platform that will be quicker and have improved visuals.

Moving forward, the team will continue to improve upon and finesse its strategies to continue meeting employees’ communication needs.

Congratulations to Seattle Children’s Hospital on this well-deserved win!

International Monetary Fund

Internal Communications Division

The IMF expertly navigates transitions and major global events

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has weathered considerable change, including global events like the COVID-19 pandemic, multiple wars, and inflation, as well as internal change, like transitioning to a hybrid work model and a wave of retirements. Its efforts in welcoming new employees and communicating with its existing workforce have earned it a win in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards in the Employee-Generated Content category.

With so much going on in the world and within the walls of IMF’s offices, the company wanted to emphasize a people-centered, empathetic communications strategy. To start, the team launched an Insider series in 2022 to spotlight priority issues and strengthen the IMF community by featuring staff voices. This multichannel digital platform included videos, blog articles (called Insider Voices), podcasts and events.

Insider Videos combine talk show-style interviews with updates so staff can learn the latest news that isn’t accessible through other communications platforms. Since its March 2022 launch, 19 episodes have been produced on diversity, equity and inclusion, gender, climate and more.

The video series has led to increased viewership of all internal videos. Insider Videos have been played over 5,500 times and received more than 16% more views on average than other internal videos.

Insider Voices are conversational and informal, a place for staff to write about both professional and personal issues that are important to them. The blog has seen more than 8,000 views and has been lauded by staff.

Insider Events are virtual, interactive discussions on current policy topics where participants can engage with speakers. Since its launch in January 2022, there have been nine events on topics such as debt, inflation and more. Events have garnered 1,800 virtual attendees.

The Insider Voice Podcast offers staff perspectives on topics in engaging conversations. The newest offering, the podcast, has released five episodes since April 2023. So far, the podcast episodes have received 1,500 plays.

As it continues to develop and tweak the format, IMF is sure to continue resonating with its workforce.

Congratulations to the team for this well-deserved win.

Orbia

One Orbia - Where Purpose Comes To Life

Bringing Orbia’s Purpose-Driven Story to Life

With a common purpose to advance life around the world, Orbia had a pressing need and opportunity: to elevate, celebrate and cultivate its present and future workforce of over 20,000 passionate, purposeful employees working across six business and over 50 countries to ensure food and food security, information access and connectivity and decarbonization and the energy transition. Orbia’s commitment to bringing this purpose to life for all its employees has earned the company a win in the Employer Branding category of Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards.

Starting with extensive internal research and conversations led by Orbia’s People team, Orbia’s employees revealed a common story of being driven by the company’s purpose to advance life around the world in their everyday work, everywhere they were located: in fact, in a 2021 survey, 86% of employees said they saw a parallel between their daily activities and Orbia’s purpose. Orbia’s purpose was a clarion call to brave, responsible and inclusive dreamers, doers and builders who were committed to changing the world, and became the foundation for Orbia’s first employer brand and employer value proposition (EVP) of “where purpose comes to life.”

From this EVP-led foundation, the Orbia team developed a visual language that utilized footprints and mirrored surfaces to reflect individual and collective steps made everywhere by employees to bring purpose to life, according to the company’s nomination form. Employee stories were identified as key components of the employer brand identity, and were collected in multiple formats and over 20 languages from team members around the world.

In advance of launching the employer brand and EVP, the Orbia team empowered over 200 champions across the company with brand messaging, materials and training to enable them to engage their colleagues and show up as ambassadors for the company’s brand story. Before the employer brand was launched, champion efforts had resulted in a 500% increase in intranet page views related to the effort without any further marketing.

Once Orbia’s employer brand and EVP was launched to the Orbia community through a virtual event in June, more than 100 locations hosted local viewing parties for over 16,000 onsite employees over 2,000 virtual employees (two times the viewership of the company’s average town hall). Following the launch festivities, 1,000 employees asked for the recording, the corresponding email about the initiative resulted in eight times the typical open rate, and social media posts announcing Orbia’s employer brand and EVP launch received an average of 9,000 views per post and a fourfold increase in clicks as well as double the engagement on Viva Engage with 23,305 views. External platforms saw a 27% increase in new followers.

Beyond activating the company’s internal community, Orbia’s employer branding and EVP initiative also caught the attention of future purpose-driven talent. Orbia’s Careers site saw a significant 17% increase in traffic and a 33% increase in users, with 33,200 new applications and 28,000 new Careers portal subscriptions following this historic launch.

Congratulations to the Orbia team for this well-deserved win!

Corvias

Leadership Development Program Launch

Corvias is fostering a culture built around care and generosity

Corvias anchors its success to three principles: being the best place to work, delivering high levels of service and giving back to its communities. In doing so, its efforts have earned it a win in Ragan’s 2024 Employee Communications Awards in the Executive/Leadership Communication category.

This initiative can be traced back to a 2022 employee engagement survey, which revealed a fragmented culture. So, the CEO appointed a working group to get to the root of the issue, learning that it came in part from different leadership styles and preferences.

To help create alignment, the team created a Leadership Development Program that was aligned with its three core principles to help identify common challenges for leaders and how to develop those careers to make the strongest leaders for the organization possible. In doing so, its goal was to receive at least 50% of attendance in training programs, improve engagement among leaders by 5% and see a 10% increase in culture sentiment from the prior year’s employee survey.

In accomplishing this mission, the team deployed three strategies:

Leverage communication channels to get feedback that can influence the training programs.

Managers and leaders made up a steering committee to influence definition of Corvias culture, while also gathering feedback from leadership and managers.

Create opportunities for more interactions between leaders and executive leaders.

Throughout the year, executives to joined teams calls, scheduled visits with operational leadership and included operational leaders in executive leadership meetings.

Ensure the leadership team is aware of learning and development opportunities.

The company CEO, CFO and COO held a kickoff event to introduce leaders to its 15 Leadership Principles, which created more natural pathways for collaboration, conversation and joining training events.
